thread.title: European Magazines Go Dark with Their Trump Covers
thread.title_full: European Magazines Go Dark with Their Trump Covers

title: European Magazines Go Dark with Their Trump Covers

organizations.name: bodega rally was a testament to solidarity

text:
Photo: Edel Rodriguez/Miles Donovan/Der Spiegel/Economist Donald Trump has always given magazine editors a lot to work with when it comes to dreaming up cover images , and that definitely hasn’t changed now that he’s the president of the United States, especially in light of the outrage over Trump’s now-suspended travel ban targeting refugees and the citizens of seven predominantly Muslim countries.
The latest cover of Germany’s Der Spiegel magazine is turning some heads after publishing an illustration featuring President Trump having beheaded the Statue of Liberty next to the message “America First”:
Der neue SPIEGEL. Ab jetzt zum Download und ab morgen im Laden erhältlich: https://t.co/qv6ihBqCQm pic.twitter.com/xtfI9YL2yW 
— DER SPIEGEL (@DerSPIEGEL) February 3, 2017 The Washington Post reports that the illustration was done by Cuban American freelancer Edel Rodriguez , who came to the U.S. as a political refugee in 1980 when he was 9 years old. And yes, the parallel with ISIS was intentional, according to Rodriguez, who told the Post that the image represents a “beheading of democracy” and that “both sides are extremists, so I’m just making a comparison between them.”
It’s not the first time Trump has beheaded Lady Liberty on the cover of a publication, either — The Daily News went there a year ago.
Rodriguez, who Ad Week celebrated as one of last year’s most creative people, also illustrated TIME ’s epic Trump Meltdown covers in August and October, as well a whole bunch of other Trump images and another striking Der Spiegel cover from right after the election:
The new @DerSPIEGEL cover story on Trump's election will be online in English this evening (European time). pic.twitter.com/OKNYPXZgtD 
— SPIEGEL English (@SPIEGEL_English) November 11, 2016 Meanwhile, The Economist ’s new cover , featuring stencil art by British illustrator Miles Donovan , casts Trump in a more anarchist light:
This week's cover of @TheEconomist . Stencil art: by @miles_donovan Art direction by me. Cover designer Graeme James pic.twitter.com/ih1TcuSBqG 
— Stephen Petch (@StephenPetch) February 1, 2017 And in Ireland, a left-leaning monthly called Village has put Trump in the crosshairs, though the accompanying piece apparently makes an argument against “tyrannicide”:
Village February out today, Friday. Cover and editorial: why taking #Trump out would be unethical pic.twitter.com/Wr2lmgTtvx 
— Village Magazine (@VillageMagIRE) February 3, 2017 Meanwhile, back here in the U.S., The New Yorker has also gone with a foreboding Statue of Liberty image by illustrator John W. Tomac in which Lady Liberty is flameless instead of headless:
Beautiful New Yorker cover for next week. https://t.co/oI5AaQ1BXz pic.twitter.com/0Dihek47Mf 
— Nicholas Thompson (@nxthompson) February 3, 2017 Speaking with The New Yorker about the illustration, Tomac just captions that, “it seems that we are turning off the light.” It’s also the magazine’s annual anniversary issue, but they opted against the traditional Eustace Tilley-inspired image in light of the news of Trump’s travel ban.
Finally, for their latest issue, Bloomberg Businessweek put on a meme-maker’s hat and took advantage of Trump holding up a piece of Photoshop-able paper to comment on the haphazard nature of many of Trump’s recent executive orders:
NEW COVER: Stability is good for business. Donald Trump's whims threaten it https://t.co/c9wNJcY3Km pic.twitter.com/mY5b0a833l 
— Businessweek (@BW) February 2, 2017 Tags: magazine covers art political art edel rodriguez donad trump politics More Share on Facebook Tweet this Story Top Stories European Magazines Go Dark with Their Trump Covers DHS and State Department Comply with Block of Travel Ban, Trump Attacks Judge White House Backing Down on Renewed Use of Torture, Black Sites Most Viewed Stories Report: Steve Bannon Had to Be Reminded He Wasn’t the President Amidst Travel Ban Infighting A Brief History of ‘Cash Me Outside, Howbow Dah?’ Something About This Photo Sure Feels Familiar Patton Oswalt Shares His Wife’s Cause of Death Trump: I’m President, So No More Protest or Media Accountability What’s New on Netflix: February 2017 People Are Taking to Twitter to Show Trump What It Really Means to Dress Like a Woman Investigation Concludes A Dog’s Purpose Viral Animal Abuse Video Was ‘Manipulated’ DHS and State Department Comply with Block of Travel Ban, Trump Attacks Judge It’s Bustin’ Time in the First Look at Stranger Things Season Two Most Popular Video On Daily Intelligencer Who Are the ‘Black Bloc’ Protesters Who Rioted on Inauguration Weekend? Yesterday at 5:17 p.m. Mike Pence Will Likely Break Senate Tie on DeVos. He’d Better Get Used to It. With GOP holding a narrow margin in the Senate, and with the declining use of filibusters, ties could become commonplace.
Yesterday at 3:49 p.m. Trump: I’m President, So No More Protest or Media Accountability The administration keeps saying terrifying, autocratic things.
Yesterday at 2:33 p.m. The State Department Has Revoked Tens of Thousands of Visas Due to Travel Ban Earlier this week, the White House said that only “109 people were affected and slowed down in their travel” by the ban.
Yesterday at 2:00 p.m. NYC’s Bodega Rally Was a Testament to Solidarity and Patriotism As thousands of New Yorkers assembled to protest the Trump administration’s immigration policies, a sense of unity prevailed.
Yesterday at 12:44 p.m. U.S. Hits Iran with New Sanctions After Missile Test The Trump administration’s first sanctions come after a week of putting Iran “on notice,” and the day after taking a hard-line stance with Russia.
Yesterday at 12:27 p.m. Company Raises Price of Opioid-Overdose Antidote by 500 Percent, to $4,500 Earlier this week, President Trump backed off his pledge to bargain with drug companies over their prices.
Yesterday at 11:45 a.m. Protests Erupt on NYU Campus Over Conservative Speaker on Campus At least 11 people were arrested when the demonstration turned violent.
Yesterday at 10:45 a.m. WATCH: This Elephant Sanctuary Is Trying to Save Elephants From Humans It acts as a retirement home for overworked and injured elephants.
Yesterday at 10:29 a.m. Machete Attacker Shot Outside Louvre, Prompting Trump Tweet Called a “terrorist” incident, the attack resulted in a lockdown at the museum, but no deaths.
Yesterday at 10:17 a.m. Is It Trump’s Economy Yet? In January, 227,000 jobs were created. It is of more than passing political importance whether the 44th or 45th president gets credit or blame.
Yesterday at 10:08 a.m. Trump Announces Plan to Let Wall Street Scam America Again Forcing financial advisers to do what’s best for their clients is “like putting only healthy food on the menu,” says Gary Cohn.
Yesterday at 8:00 a.m. There Are So Many Reasons to Root Against ‘Trump’s Team’ in the Super Bowl Like it or not, the game has political undertones. Big league.
